q: What is a relation between two sets?
a: A relation \(R\) from set \(A\) to set \(B\) is a subset of their Cartesian product: \(R \subseteq A \times B\). If \((a,b) \in R\), we write \(aRb\).

q: What is a relation on a set?
a: A relation on a set \(A\) is any subset of \(A \times A\). Thus, both elements of each ordered pair belong to the same set \(A\).
A relation \(R\) on set \(A\) is **reflexive** if \((a,a) \in R\) for all \(a \in A\).
A relation \(R\) on set \(A\) is **symmetric** if \((a,b) \in R\) implies \((b,a) \in R\), for all \(a,b \in A\).
A relation \(R\) on set \(A\) is **transitive** if \((a,b) \in R\) and \((b,c) \in R\) together imply \((a,c) \in R\), for all \(a,b,c \in A\).

q: When is a relation called an equivalence relation?
a: A relation is an **equivalence relation** if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

q: What is the set of all equivalence classes of an equivalence relation?
a: It forms a **partition** of the set \(A\). Each element belongs to exactly one equivalence class.
A **function** \(f\) from set \(A\) to set \(B\) is a special relation where every element of \(A\) has **exactly one** image in \(B\). Denoted \(f: A \to B\).

q: What is the domain, co-domain, and range of a function?
a:
For \(f: A \to B\):  
• **Domain** = set \(A\).  
• **Co-domain** = set \(B\).  
• **Range** = \(\{ f(x) : x \in A \} \subseteq B\).
A function \(f: A \to B\) is **one-one** if \(f(x_1) = f(x_2) \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2\). Each element of \(B\) has at most one pre-image.
A function \(f: A \to B\) is **onto** if for every \(b \in B\), there exists at least one \(a \in A\) such that \(f(a) = b\). Thus, Range(f) = Co-domain.
A function is **bijective** if it is both one-one and onto. A bijective function establishes a one-to-one correspondence between elements of \(A\) and \(B\).

q: What is the composition of functions?
a:
If \(f: A \to B\) and \(g: B \to C\), the **composition** of \(f\) and \(g\) is \(g \circ f: A \to C\) defined by  
\[(g \circ f)(x) = g(f(x))\]  
for all \(x \in A\), provided Range(f) ⊆ Domain(g).

A function \(f: A \to B\) is **invertible** if there exists a function \(g: B \to A\) such that  
\[g(f(x)) = x, \; \forall x \in A\]  and  
\[f(g(y)) = y, \; \forall y \in B.\]  
Then \(g\) is called the **inverse function** of \(f\), denoted by \(f^{-1}\).

q: When does a function have an inverse?
a: A function has an inverse **if and only if** it is bijective (one-one and onto).

q: State the property of inverse function composition.
a:
If \(f\) is invertible, then  
\[f^{-1} \circ f = I_A \quad \text{and} \quad f \circ f^{-1} = I_B\]  
where \(I_A\) and \(I_B\) are identity functions on sets \(A\) and \(B\).

Let \(f(x) = 3x + 2\). Then, to find \(f^{-1}\):  
\(y = 3x + 2 \Rightarrow x = \frac{y - 2}{3}\).  
Hence \(f^{-1}(y) = \frac{y - 2}{3}\).
